content.introText:
Who lives here? Who can afford to live here?

You can use this site to look at income demographics and rents in neighborhoods all over New York City.

 When you click on a neighborhood, you'll map the number of families in each income category on the multicolored bar at the bottom of the page.

Come inside to see how it works and why it matters!

content.rentIntroText:
Who Can Afford to Live Here?

What's 'affordable'?
 The government says that housing is 'affordable' if you spend 30% or less of your income to live there.

The bottom number on this color bar translates your annual income into 'affordable' monthly rent. Thirty percent of $20,000 per year, for instance, is $500 per month.

Use the rent sliders to estimate how much it costs to rent a one-, two-, and three-bedroom apartment in that neighborhood.
content.whatNowText: To learn more about how affordable housing works in your neighborhood, order or download the book 'What Is Affordable Housing?' or order the 'What Is Affordable Housing?' workshop kit. Find out more here.

mfi.mfiDescription:
The bar below shows the income categories that the government uses to decide who is eligible for different affordable housing programs. These categories are expressed as percentages of the Median Family Income.

The MFI for a family of four in Greater New York (which includes the City and some of its suburbs) is $85,900 per year.
mfi.mfiTip0: Extremely Low Income runs from 0% to 30% of MFI, or from $0 to $25,750 in income for a family of four.
mfi.mfiTip1: Very Low Income runs from 30% to 50% of MFI, or from $$25,750 to $42,950 in income for a family of four.
mfi.mfiTip2: Low Income runs from 50% to 100% of MFI, or from $42,950 to $68,7000 in income for a family of four.
mfi.mfiTip3: Moderate Income runs from 100% to 120% of MFI, or from $68,700 to $103,080 in income for a family of four.
mfi.mfiTip4: Middle Income runs from 120% to 230% of MFI, or from $103,080 to $200,000 in income for a family of four.
mfi.mfiTip5: High Income is above 230% of MFI, or above $200,000 in income for a family of four.
